ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the history of electromagnetism

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Maybe it's just me, but I was expecting more history and less physics than there was in the class.

This class had almost no structure, which made it very difficult to engage. It also seemed like work was created randomly just because, and in combination with a lack of clear deadlines, no one knew what was due and when. Our time in class could also be cumbersome because it was often just a lecture instead of a discussion. Overall there wasn't much communication from the instructors, and there was little feedback on our work. With all this said, the class has a really interesting topic, and I appreciated that we were allowed some freedom in how we engaged with it. It was so cool to go to west campus and get a close-up look at historical scientific instruments, and I appreciated the free range we had for final projects.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If this class is ever taught again, go in knowing that more than other classes you'll get out of it what you put in. The course made me think about electromagnetism in interesting ways, but it felt like those thoughts didn't really go anywhere. I'd recommend this class if you want something chill without much reading or homework, and are organized enough to keep track of what is due and when. I'd mainly recommend to people already interested in the topic, though.
